article-meta.aff: 1Department of Pathology, Creighton University Medical Center, Omaha, NE, USA
2Center for Health Policy & Ethics, Creighton University School of Medicine, Omaha, NE, USA

author-notes.corresp: Roger A. Brumback, MD, Department of Pathology, Creighton University Medical Center, Omaha, NE 68144 Email: rogerbrumback@creighton.edu

body.p:
Genetics is a “hot topic” in medicine at the beginning of the 21st century. However, it is remarkable to realize that some of the major scientific advances in genetics are less than 60 years old (which is just slightly more than 2 human generations 1 ). Many of these developments 2 related to the biochemical nature of genes, including the famous 1953 discovery of the structure of deoxyribonucleic acid (DNA) by James Watson and Francis Crick 3 and the subsequent unraveling of the DNA code by Marshall Nirenberg. 4 However, a major turning point in human genetics was the discovery in 1956 by Joe-Hin Tjio and Albert Levan 5,6 that by properly visualizing chromosomes, the normal human diploid chromosome number could be identified as only 46. This opened the path for the discovery by Jérôme Lejeune, Marthe Gautier, and Raymond Turpin of the abnormal chromosome number (trisomy chromosome 21) that characterizes Down syndrome 7 and the subsequent explosive growth of cytogenetic studies in the 1960s and 1970s, with continuing interest well into the new millenium (even the Journal of Child Neurology published 8 articles 8
–15 focused on cytogenetics in 2011). One of the well-published pioneers in cytogenetic studies was the distinguished pediatric hematologist Park Spearin Gerald, 16
–130 working at the Children’s Hospital Medical Center and Harvard Medical School in Boston, Massachusetts.

Park S. Gerald was the younger son of Herbert Franklin “Pop” Gerald (born September 5, 1881, in Massachusetts), who was a long-tenured (38 years) faculty member of the Creighton University School of Medicine. 131 Pop Gerald received a PhG degree in 1902 from the Massachusetts College of Pharmacy in Boston and an MD degree in 1909 from Medical School of Tufts College in Boston. In 1910 he was a house officer at the Worcester City Hospital in Worcester, Massachusetts, where he met and subsequently married a nurse Emma Florence Park (who had been born in the Philippines and was about 8 years his junior). They moved to Omaha, Nebraska, in 1912 where Pop Gerald joined the faculty of Creighton University as an Assistant in Pharmacology in the School of Medicine. After moving to Omaha, the couple had 2 children: Curtis Franklin Gerald (born May 22, 1915) and Park Spearin Gerald (born June 30, 1921). Pop Gerald ascended through the academic ranks at Creighton University to become Chairman of the Department of Physiology in 1930 (a position he held for 20 years). Pop Gerald was considered a superb teacher and role model by students and an advocate for the principles of ethical medical practice before that concept became popular in the latter part of the 20th century. Pop Gerald obviously instilled these same attributes into his son Park Gerald who, after graduating from the Omaha North High School in 1939, attended the Iowa State College of Agriculture and Mechanical Arts in Ames, Iowa (Figure 1), where he received a BS degree in 1943. Park Gerald then attended Creighton University School of Medicine, graduating with an MD degree in 1947 (Figure 2). He was a pediatric intern at the Strong Memorial Hospital of the University of Rochester School of Medicine and Dentistry in Rochester, New York.

caption.p: In 1942, Park S. Gerald served as treasurer for the Iowa State College Chemical Society, as noted in The Bomb (the college yearbook published annually from 1893 to 1994). Used with permission from Special Collections Department of Iowa State University Library.
The 1947 graduation photograph of Park S. Gerald from Creighton University School of Medicine (left) and a 30 years later 1977 photograph showing him in relaxed conversation (right).

body.p: In 1948, Park began his research career with Benjamin M. Kagan in the Kunstadter Laboratories for Pediatric Research in the Medical Research Institute and the Sarah Morris Hospital for Children of the Michael Reese Hospital in Chicago, Illinois, and produced his first 3 publications. 127 –129 Then, in 1951, he entered the Unites States Army Medical Corps, serving as a pediatrician at the 11th Field Hospital in Augsburg, Germany. 132 From 1953 to 1955, Park completed his pediatric training as a junior and a senior assistant resident at the Harvard Medical School–affiliated Children’s Medical Center in Boston, Massachusetts. In 1955, he began a prestigious research fellowship with the “father of pediatric hematology” Louis K. Diamond 133,134 (whose son Jared Diamond is an award-winning author 135 ). Two years later, Park made the first of his breakthrough discoveries, characterizing a hereditary hemoglobinopathy that results in methemoglobinemia. 126 Capitalizing on the starch block electrophoresis technique then just developed by Henry G. Kunkel 136 (father of Louis M. Kunkel, whose laboratory discovered the dystrophin gene that underlies Duchenne/Becker muscular dystrophy 137 –139 ), Park was able to devise a diagnostic test for β-thalassemia 125 by showing an increased percentage of hemoglobin A2. He subsequently described hemoglobin Lepore, which was the first example of a hemoglobin fusion protein (between the delta-globin gene and the beta-globin gene). 124 For his groundbreaking work on hemoglobinopathies, Park received the E. Mead Johnson Award for Research in Pediatrics 109 from the Society for Pediatric Research in 1962 (the same year that pediatric nephrologist Robert L. Vernier of the University of Minnesota was also honored).

In 1958, Diamond sent Park to study in England with Professor Lionel Penrose, 140 Galton Chair of Eugenics and Director of the Galton Laboratory at University College, London. During that fellowship, Park recognized the importance of cytogenetics to pediatrics and on his return to Boston in 1959 established one of the first human genetics training programs in the United States, as well as a genetics research laboratory 107 (Figure 3), focusing on cytogenetics (the timing happening to coincide with the discovery of the chromosomal abnormality characterizing Down syndrome 7 ). With the same vigor he had demonstrated in studying hemoglobinopathies, Park pursued a variety of chromosomal investigations. In recognition of his many accomplishments in the Harvard Medical School, Park was promoted to the rank of Associate Professor of Pediatrics (with Tenure) in 1967 and Professor of Pediatrics in 1970. Earlier in the 1960s, Park had declined to accept the position of Chairman of the Department of Pediatrics at the Washington University School of Medicine in St Louis, Missouri, but instead highly recommended his Harvard Medical School colleague Philip R. Dodge to that search committee (this was a prescient recommendation, because Dodge subsequently transformed not only pediatrics at the St Louis Children’s Hospital but also child neurology in the United States 141
–145 ).

caption.p: Park S. Gerald in his laboratory at Children’s Medical Center, Boston, Massachusetts, in 1964.

body.p:
Through his research endeavors, Park initially identified a number of chromosome aberrations in children. 78,89,93,96,98,103 In 1968, he launched into a National Institutes of Health (NIH)–funded survey of the karyotypes of all newborns delivered at the Boston Lying-In Hospital. 74,88 This project was undertaken not just to understand the frequency of chromosomal aberrations in live-born infants but also to identify and then to provide careful follow-up by the child psychiatrist Stanley Walzer for those infants with sex chromosome aneuploidies because of public concern about possible deviant behavior by males with sex chromosome aneuploidy. 42 The public alarm about potential criminal tendencies of males with XXY and particularly XYY karyotypes had been sounded by studies of institutions in the United Kingdom and the United States that showed an increased incidence of such sex chromosome aneuploidy in imprisoned male criminals. 146
–153 This was followed by sensational but false news reports that Richard Speck (who brutally murdered eight Chicago nurses in July 1966) should be excused because he had an XYY karyotype 154 and by the use of “crime chromosome” 155,156 as a criminal defense strategy by some attorneys. Although Park was able to generate important epidemiologic information about the incidence of various karyotypic anomalies, 74,88 an unexpected outcry of ethical concerns raised by Jon Beckwith and Jonathan King about stigmatizing infants as potential criminals based on cytogenetic findings caused Park to rethink the value of the research. He decided in 1974 to end the study. 156
–163

By the early 1970s, several discoveries had revolutionized chromosome analysis. The major discovery was the ability to differentially stain the chromosomes to aid in identification. The first of these techniques used fluorescent dyes to produce bands. 164 The fleeting nature of the fluorescence staining soon led to development of a more stable banding procedure using Giemsa stain. 165 Thus, each chromosome could be more accurately identified and small changes (such as deletions) in individual chromosomes could be visualized. Another discovery was that cultured human cells could be fused with cultured mouse cells to produce mouse-human hybrid cells that contained in the nucleus the full complements of mouse and human chromosomes 166 ; however, with successive divisions, these hybrid cells would throw out individual human chromosomes. 167 This allowed investigators to identify metabolic signatures associated with the presence or absence of specific human chromosomes, thus mapping proteins and enzymes to specific chromosomes. 168 Park immediately exploited these discoveries in his research laboratory. 40, 44–49, 54, 55, 58–60, 65, 69, 76, 83, 84. His important technical note on producing hybrid cells using polyethylene glycol has been cited more than 500 times. 58

Park was also visionary in identifying the need for expansion of the research programs at the Children’s Hospital. In the late 1960s, he planned and designed a new building that opened in 1970 and was named the John F. Enders Pediatric Research Laboratory after the Nobel Laureate Enders who, while working at Children’s Hospital, made the groundbreaking discovery of how to grow poliovirus in culture. 169

In 1979, Park was recognized with the second annual Distinguished Research Award of the Association for Retarded Citizens for his devotion to studying genetic disorders, many of which adversely affect the brain.

As the 1970s wound down, Park developed an interest in the then still embryonic field of personal computers and began to develop software to store and retrieve genetic data and pushed for the use of personal computers by investigators at Children’s Hospital until his retirement from the Harvard Medical School in 1981. Subsequently, his first love, cytogenetics, appeared to be eclipsed by the excitement of molecular biology and the subsequent quest to unravel the human genome. Nonetheless, cytogenetics as pioneered by Park remains an important tool 165 in general pediatrics as well as pediatric neurology.

Throughout his career, Park was not just a brilliant and insightful investigator, but also a wonderful and supportive mentor to countless junior faculty, fellows, pediatric residents, and students (including one of the authors of this tribute 84,170 ). Ellen Song Kang (retired Professor of Pediatrics and Pharmacology at the University of Tennessee Health Science Center, who was mentored 71 –73,79
–82,85 by Park as she was developing a career at Children’s Hospital from 1967 to 1972) summarized her feelings toward him as follows:
Park had a way of accommodating just about all the strange medical creatures in the world. Here was that girl from Hawaii who was Korean by ancestry, yet born in the USA. She spoke good English and she graduated from Stanford Medical School. Yet, she was distinctly Asian. Never mind those things, she was interested in the metabolic end of all those genetic conditions, but not at all in the structures that regulated them—the chromosomes. Since metabolic diseases needed a lot of chemical backup, he sought help with someone in nephrology, Dr Francis Fellers, who allowed her some space in his laboratory and shared his instruments for her to use. Also, since metabolic diseases had a lot of neurological side effects, he allowed her to work with Dr Randolph Byers to see patients and train with him in order for her to manage her metabolically afflicted patients. Later, Dr Richmond Paine took over in neurology as Dr Byers retired, but the agreement continued. She even worked on an NIH project checking on the developmental status of patients under Dr Paine's project for financial support. All this while Park counted her part of his genetics group. How awesome!! Now in retrospect, I admire him for having allowed me to follow this path without keeping me tethered to the conventional routine most others would have taken. This path allowed me the freedom of thought and pursuit of ideas that led me on to a very fulfilling career.

After his retirement, Park pursued his passion for computers as vigorously as he had pursued his genetics research, being very active in the Boston Computer Society 171 (interestingly, his brother Curtis, with a chemical engineering doctorate from the Massachusetts Institute of Technology in Cambridge, Massachusetts, was a computer science professor and author of a popular college computer science text 172,173 ). Based on a lifetime of remarkable achievement in the field of pediatrics, Creighton University in 1985 recognized his distinguished career with the Alumni Achievement Citation. Park died on July 9, 1993, not long after celebrating his 72nd birthday.

ack.title: Acknowledgments
ack.p: We thank Dr Ellen Song Kang for allowing us to use her comments about Park Gerald and we thank Park Gerald’s son Clif Gerald for providing us with the 1977 photograph. The first author (RAB) worked in the laboratory of Park S. Gerald during 1970. The second author (RLO) was familiar with Park’s studies because of his own research and, as Dean of the Creighton University School of Medicine and Vice President for Health Sciences, nominated Park Gerald for the Alumni Achievement Citation.

fn.label: Author Contributions
fn.p: The authors jointly conceived the article and conducted necessary background research for information and pictures. RAB drafted the article and RLO provided review and revisions.

fn.label: Declaration of Conflicting Interests
fn.p: The authors declared no potential conflicts of interest with respect to the research, authorship, and/or publication of this article.

fn.label: Funding
fn.p: The authors received no financial support for the research, authorship, and/or publication of this article.
